Articles.Content:
I had an issue that I couldn't figure out how to fix for over a week so I made a post. Found a resolution to the issue on my own but no way in the UI to delete my own post.

Edited April 19, 2021 by VanquishedWolf

Generally, the moderators around here want to keep everything permanently for historical purposes, so they don't delete anything.

However, if you really want your thread to die, then look in the upper right hand corner of your post for 3 dots. Click that. See it says "Report"? Click that, and report your own thread to the moderators. In the box, explain that it's your own thread and you figured out your answer for yourself, and you want your thread to die. They will probably lock it for you.

Also however -- sometimes it's a good idea to leave your own question there, and write your own answer to your own question, for the enlightenment of future generations -- rather than killing it.
This question about the forums has been moved to the Kerbal Network.

16 hours ago, bewing said:

Also however -- sometimes it's a good idea to leave your own question there, and write your own answer to your own question, for the enlightenment of future generations -- rather than killing it.

Ya tbh I have no idea what I did that fixed my issue, I had a launch of probes, all of which had partial control even though they had 100% signal and probe cores were on. After copying a lot of game files into an external folder, overwriting my save, then reloading the original save just after docking with the space station then all of the probe cores were hibernating. Went into my VAB and checked the probes in the subassembly, hibernation on, checked the vessel I originally put them into the subassembly from and the probe was not hibernating. No idea how it was caused or resolved. So didn't feel it contained valuable enough information for anyone looking for a resolution to a similar issue.
